Sir, in 54:39. You say that Fn=mg/cos theta.  So the normal force(reaction) is greater than the wieght how thas possible?

Your illustration of a car making a turn in a semi-circular path is quite confusing. Is your illustration showing a bird's eye view of the path of the car? Or were you trying to illustrate a curved path or road that is banked?  If the road is just a curved but flat surface, there is no normal force directed to the center of curvature. So, the source of centripetal force is still static friction. Assuming you were referring to a banked and curved road, proper vector analysis of the situation will show that the normal force (always perpendicular to the surface of the banked road) is NOT exactly the centripetal force needed for a car to make a perfect maneuver. There is a component of this normal force that should be determined and is considered the centripetal force. It's hard to show the diagram here but I suggest you check any reliable Physics textbooks (such as Young's University Physics) what I am talking about.

35:14 he mixed up the equations for point C and point A, at point C, T= Fc + mg, because weight acts downwards, and at that point, so does the centripetal force.   At point A, the equation is T=Fc (or normal force in this case) minus the mg.

@richardsong5305  I understood why it is mg/cos. Look at the free body diagram at 54:37   , the Normal force is being decomposed, so the force which supports the weight force mg is actually the vertical component of the normal force Fn. The vertical component is related to the angle theta by Fn*cos(theta). Hence, since the weightforce mg is supported by the vertical component of Fn, which is Fn*cos(theta), we find the normal force Fn by setting them equal. mg=Fn*cos(theta). From this equation you can dervie that Fn=mg/cos(theta).That's how I understood it.

@bilalsheikh5786  got it. It is larger than the mg with the force that is opposite to the centripetal.

Ok so basically, v^2/r is correct for the acceleration, because it is part of the mv^2/r equation for centripetal force in Newtons. A different formula for acceleration only to be used when involving time would be 4π^2r/t^2, which he uses sometimes. Once more, V^2/r and the one with "π" in it both give acceleration, and you can easily find the force by multiplying by mass (ma=F).

It's just exposure. You learn linear motions first, such as Newton's First, Second and Third law, kinematic equations etc. Then you move onto rotational motions and learn all the new formulas for that. Then it's a case of substituting what you know. The more you do trig, algebra and these kind of problems, the more it clicks. Some people instantly see it, others don't, but that's the whole point of learning. I'm sure OP wasn't a born mathematician or physicist from the womb.

Just volunteering to reply.  We denote acceleration in metres per second squared meaning  that the velocity increases by the same magnitude very consecutive second, for example-15 ms^2 means for 1st second is 15 metres, second second is 30 metres, 3rd second is 45 metres and so on. In other words at the 4th second, the instantaneous velocity is 50 ms.

It's because you have to break up forces into parallel and perpendicular components to the centripetal line. The centripetal line is horizontal so mg is already perpendicular to it. Therefore, only the normal force has to be broken up into its parallel and perpendicular components. If you break up mg, they can be parallel and perpendicular to the surface but it wouldn't be to the centripetal line and that's why you get an error.

When two surfaces are sliding pass each other, there is kinetic friction.  When the surfaces are not sliding pass each other such as when a block is at rest, there is static friction.  During rolling motion without slipping, the surface of the wheel and the floor are not sliding pass each other and therefore there is static friction even if the wheel is moving.  Watch out for this one!
So static friction can be perpendicular to the direction the thing moving?

In the problem at 47:53, static friction can prevent the car from skidding to the east or west while the car is moving north.  While it prevents skidding in these directions, the surface of the wheel and the ground are not sliding pass each other so static friction is active in this instance and not kinetic friction.  In icy / snowy conditions when there's less friction on a road, it's easy for a vehicle traveling north to lose control and skid to the right or to the left.  Once the vehicle begins to skid to the right, the surface of the wheel and the ground are now sliding pass each other.  Kinetic friction takes over and it will be directed toward the left.  Friction is always opposes motion.  In this example, it seems counterintuitive that static friction should be to the left ./ west while the car is moving north.  However, this static friction is not opposing the northbound  motion of the car but it's prevented the tendency of the vehicle to skid to the east while making a circular turn to the west and so static friction is directed west opposite to the eastward skidding motion.
